title: How do we get racist people to stop being racist? - Quora

response.answer_text: My own family has a deeply sad and brutal relationship with racism so this question really hits a nerve. Both my mother's side of the family and also my father's side has an unfortunate history with racism which runs deep and ugly. One side has a happy ending, the other does not. Racism is a social problem and can involve group behavior, yet at it's root is is an individual perception issue. So the crux of the issue is how to alter individual people's perceptions of those of a differing race. Sounds like a highly improbable pipe dream? My grandmother is a case in point that people can change their racist views. Grandmother Lillian was a racist individual who changed her mind after positive one on one contact, consistently over time completely exposed her to individuals of color, and she did a 180 degree whole-hearted change in her views on race. My grandmother was an Appalachian poor white woman in Tennessee coal mining country who detested black people and really any people of color. So the ultimate irony is her son, my father, married a hispanic woman, my mother, when working onsite in Texas where my hispanic mother was the office secretary. Love bloomed, marriage followed. My grandmother was beside herself, but she loved the resulting grand babies, my sister and I. Someone mentioned this in their answer than contact with mixed race children can alter a racist's perceptions of discrimination and I think for my Grandmother this was true as she softened a bit, but not totally in her racism. Then years later on my Grandmother became ill and guess who is her devoted and super kind daily at-home aid? An angelic black woman named Ruby who cared for her until her death. So the two people who washed Lillian, fed her, cared for her until my Grandmother's dying breath were ** drumroll** totally dark skinned people. Fate has a good sense of humor sometimes. My grandmother Lillian doted on Ruby and felt a fierce sense of loyalty to her, and grudgingly learned to admire my own hispanic mother and the resentment about dark skinned people faded in time. She realized her own distorted views on race were purely based on a stupid social construct house of cards and they all crumpled to the floor. However, not one single government entity can legislate anti-racism thoughts. Sure, legislation can make it against the law to dish out racist-based action in the work place, or in housing, or other areas of social contact. Society can exert change toward racism by making outward forms of racism illegal, difficult to achieve, and be considered gauche or socially in poor taste. But the pure change of heart, the hidden deep inner views on racism don't even exist within the domain of social laws, but rather it lives and breathes in the realms of psychological and cognitive issues, and is a highly individual subjective thing. How can laws change psychological views? Laws cannot change inner personal psychology. However, over time shifts in society do happen. Look, just a bit over 150 years ago blacks as slaves was considered simply doing business, so society and social norms do shift over time. The dark sticky and ugly reality of racism is something which permeates all societies around the globe, sometimes overtly and often moreseo covertly. All those advertisements in various cultures such as India on how to obtain whiter skin for women? Yeah, that is racism just as much as a shouted spittle-flying racial slur, it just doesn't seem as oppressive or hostile while existing uncomfortably but more benignly under the cover of "beauty." Even business can be complicit in perpetuating racism if it makes a buck doing so. How can we stop people being racist? We give people more opportunities for one on one contact with those of differing races, to allow for more face to face contact. Laws don't alter people's views on those of other races, rather one on one personal contact can. This made a difference for my grandmother. Getting to know ONE black person up close and personal in an organic way which unfolded over time was the magic ticket for my Grandmother. She learned that people are people regardless of their skin color, but that "aha!" understanding took time, it took extended contact and a genuine connection to Ruby to unlearn all her racism. Whether that means keeping some affirmative action quotas or mixing up races as often as possible in efforts to get races in contact with each other, I don't know. But this is tricky business as sometimes forced intervention to undo decades and centuries of racism can backfire and races can feel pitted against each other when integration is a zero sum game of competition for spaces in school, or jobs. The nuance often gets totally lost and racism can often grow as a result of too heavy handed an effort at anti-racism or anti-discrimination social engineering. Genuine change is often not a matter of legislation. Racist people only stop being racist when their world view is not only challenged it is upended entirely and a personal friendship with someone of a differing race which blossoms organically isn't something which can be legislated or forced but it can be encouraged due to circumstances. One friendship can make a huge difference, one deep genuine contact. One person can change it all.

In my 29 years of life, I’ve increasingly noticed that if I want anything to change in any kind of situation, lecturing doesn’t work. If I’m in an argument with someone and I really want them to understand my feelings, treating them like they need to be educated or “enlightened” has never been successful long term (or short term really). Nor has attacking people personally, regardless of how wrong they are. For instance, in my experience “shut up and listen old privileged white man” rarely is responded to with, “sure, I’m so sorry about the way I was acting”. Haha, yeah no, these tactics rarely garner reflection and change. Instead they incite and provoke deeper hatred and violence towards people like me. It’s widely assumed that “awareness” is the answer to all the world’s problems. It is an easy solution because, I mean, who doesn’t love to sit on a soapbox and tweet your angst out to whoever will listen, right? Feels great to preach— especially if there’s a hint of ridicule and sarcasm, too! And now we can sort of piggyback off of other people’s clever attacks and feel even more clever and self-righteous when we re-tweet or re-post a Facebook status. Great for the ego, but I’m not so sure it’s great for the problem. You can’t drive out hate with hate-MLK. What might the world be like if race wasn’t important. I mean if every image of beauty, intellect, health, brilliance, generosity, love, etc, is white or predominantly white, then race is most certainly still too significant. But if the world could treat skin colour as it treats, I dunno, finger shape or something, then we’ll have made real progress. When it ACTUALLY just doesn’t matter. And obviously we need to stop using terms “black” and “white” as descriptors—Dated inappropriate terminology with way too many powerful associations. Less preaching would help exponentially. Less ad hominem attacks. Less isolationist tribal sounding rhetoric—such as anti-white man rhetoric which seems to be popping right now. Truth is, white people don't suffer from their racially-contentious rhetoric. They don’t. They get to spew what they want and then go back to being worshipped— even by those they are criticizing. But dark-skinned people like me have to deal with the lasting effects of resentment and hate that is often deepened by this sort of crap. It’s human nature for people to respond negatively to attacks on character. It’s partly why so many people have stopped going to church. Who wants to be told they’re an unholy sinner who needs reform and that they’re going to hell unless they do a,b,c etc? Unless you’re already on that bus, it’s hard to attract people to it. And it’s no wonder! Duh! How different is that rhetoric from “you privileged white xenophobic man you need reform”? Generally, people don’t respond positively to rhetoric that labels them negatively, is accusatory, and demands them to change. Heck think about relationships. I had a friend who really hurt me deeply. I hardly accused him, but merely mentioning that I was hurt and wanted to talk to him,(even with no label or accusation, and no request for reform) caused him to avoid me like the plague. Sigh, 50 going on 12 as they say. Frustrating, indeed… but human. We’re all just humans. If change is indeed the aim, then it has to be a bigger priority than momentary self-gratification. Being an asshole to assholes has never worked. And historically, the vulnerable ones have paid the price. If a comment hits a particular white man the wrong way one morning, the witty outspoken white man or woman who posted the comment won’t pay. It’ll be the black guy who he decides to pull over and bully that morning, or the Indigenous woman he gropes angrily, or the black woman he humiliates in the workplace who pays. Get it? At the risk of abusing an adage, MLK didn’t die because of his unyielding desire to “put whites in their place” or cause more disunity. He died as a result of his efforts to END segregation, to eliminate tribalism. His dream was that little white boys and little black girls would join hands. Try and remember that. If we want the world to treat non-white people better, bullying the bullies is not the answer. No, if we want people to see us as fully human and beautiful, race as a whole needs to become LESS significant, not more significant.

You can’t. You cannot stop racism. You cannot kill it. You cannot regulate it out of existence. You cannot force it to go away. In fact, trying to get rid of racism only creates more racism… especially if you are trying to get rid of racism by more racism. The only way for racism to disappear is to let it die. As long as the laws make everyone legally equal in their opportunities, the social aspect of racism will fade. It takes generations to do so. You cannot force it. You can only ignore it. Ignore race in general. Children will grow up seeing their grumpy racist parents or grandparents and not understand, because society will have moved on. They may pick up this racism if it’s taught to them, but they’ll be in the extreme minority. Many more will simply move on with their lives, because race doesn’t mean anything to them, because nothing in their life is even remotely affected by their race. You cannot kill racism, not even with kindness. You can only let it die by ignoring it. Anything more, any definition of race or special privileges or ‘evening the playing field’? All that does is continue racism. What’s really weird is I don’t even understand racism against Jewish people. How do you know what a ‘Jewish’ person looks like? Jewish people look like a lot of things, even ethnic Jews. It’s not like with ‘black’ people where you can at least point at skin tone and say “they are black” (and really, even that’s not so cut and dry, but certainly more so). I don’t get it. I wish we could just stop thinking in race. Sure, white and black and asian are decent descriptors, but why do we need to attach more than simple physical description to people we don’t know? I will never understand. I don’t know what the difference is supposed to be.

There are two paths that work. This answer portrays the importance of one-on-one contact, Getting to know people who seem different from ourselves is important. The other way to end racism is educational. Not education about racism being wrong. It doesn’t work. Education that appeals to the selfish interests of the racist can ease racism. What am I talking about? Here is what we know scientifically: Negative emotions are indicators that your mind and/or body are experiencing stress. When you look at someone and judge them to be bad in some way, you believe the negative emotion affirms the rightness of your point of view because when you think of that person or people like them, you feel negative emotion. Researchers changed the definition of the purpose of emotions in 2007. The purpose of negative emotion is not to affirm your perspective about someone or something. The purpose of negative emotion is to let you know that the perspective you are taking is not the healthiest perspective you can take about the situation or person. Healthy for whom? Healthy for you! Racists not only spread stress to those they view in a negative light, they also experience higher stress every time they see or interact with people they’ve chosen to see as bad, less than, or in a negative light for some reason. While the people who are the subject of their racism can find perspectives about racists that lower the amount of stress they experience as the result of racism (and should for their own well-being), I’ll focus on the health of the racist because selfish best-interest is a motivator. Chronic stress is responsible, at the root cause, for between 66 - 99% of all physical illnesses. Different researchers cite different numbers but they are all very clear that chronic stress is detrimental to physical health. All mental illnesses are preceded by chronic stress. Racism is self-imposed chronic stress on the racist.  An aside: If someone who is the subject of racism knows this, it can be used to mentally feel better. This racist is being bad to me but he’s also harming himself and is ignorant of that fact. He thinks I’m the ignorant one but in fact his attitude makes his life much worse than it could be and how much his idiocy affects me is largely up to me. It can feel better to think that someone who is attempting to harm you is harming themselves (shooting themselves in the foot). Anything you can do to make yourself feel better that isn’t illegal and doesn’t worsen the situation for you reduces the stress you experience.  This issue, racism, and other forms of discrimination, is one reason I am so passionate about teaching people how to understand the revised scientific definition of the purpose of emotions. When emotions are accurately interpreted using the new definition, people become self-correcting. We want to feel good. We can’t feel good and find fault with others. Now I hear people saying there are bad people whom we should find fault with. The truth is that we can disagree with behavior but if we focus on the behavior and not what we’d like instead and how to get more of what we want, we will be stressed. If, in the moment we decide we don’t like something (i.e. criminal behavior) we shift our attention to solutions, “How can crime be prevented at the level of primary prevention?” for example, we feel less bad and can feel excited to be working on, finding, and implementing solutions that will help everyone. Another aspect of the new definition is that positive emotions guide us toward self-actualization. The benefits (health, career, and relationship) of positive emotions has been heavily documented during the past couple of decades. In other words, what we want lies in the direction of positive emotions. Hate, distrust, seeing others as less than, seeing self as unworthy, and other negative emotions associated with racism are unhealthy. On a very personal level, racism harms the racist. Racism also harms the racist in a larger framework. Racism worsens the health of both the racist and their targets. The cost of health and availability of health care affects everyone. Increased usage of health care increases costs and we all bear some of that burden. So, using science, we can prove that being a racist is: A personal choiceCurableHarmful to the racist on a very personal levelWhile I agree that being a racist is wrong and unfair, those arguments will never change the mind of a racist. Self-interest can and will change minds. I was not raised to be a racist. I was raised to be a nationalist, to see Americans as better and to hate Russians (it was during the cold war). After I began applying the new definition of emotions in my life and managing my emotions so that I felt good, I recognized that I couldn’t see American as better or hate Russians (or anyone) and feel as good as I want to feel. My best friends aren’t Americans (One is an Aussie, one is a citizen of the UK but originally born in South Africa and left after being persecuted under Apartheid, and another is a UK citizen who lives in the US, and another is Canadian). I do have American friends but my nationalist attitude completely changed. I even have Russian friends. I’ve written before about a night when my Russian friends and I laughed over the fact that at one time we dutifully hated one another in obedience to our government’s encouragement. Self-interest, when the purpose and use of emotions is understood, can change mental attitudes. I teach people about the new definition of emotions and how to apply it. I do not tell racists that it will make them want to stop being racists because they would not want to use it. Our minds want to protect our established beliefs. If they learn how to use the new definition and apply it, they will get their on their own. When you master skills that allow you to feel good simply because you want to feel good, it is exhilarating. You work on finding ways to soothe the rough edges of your life. It doesn’t matter if you’re a homeless addict or a CEO, we all want to feel better. When you learn how, it’s almost addictive. It’s like sanding a piece of wood. When you get the large rough edges off, the smaller ones become apparent and you work on those. There is no end to how good you can feel if you are willing to adjust your perspectives towards those that feel better. When someone is not happy, the negative emotional hit of being a racist (or a nationalist, or sexist, or homophobic) doesn’t stick out like a sore thumb. But give that person tools that help them soothe the rough edges of their life and they will quickly realize that every time they think racist thoughts they feel worse, they will begin working on it because they selfishly want to feel better. I am not saying selfish is wrong. In this case, selfish best interests are aligned with the best interests of others. In fact, when folks are happy, selfish best interests are aligned with the well-being of others. When you actually feel great, it feels far better when others feel good, too. Happy people are nicer to strangers, they’re better corporate citizens, and they are unlikely to commit crimes. Selfish can lead to harm when people don’t feel good emotionally and don’t have healthy skills to feel better. It’s difficult to ask, “What would be better for the racist?” and see this solution. Our tendency is to punish the racist. There are no solutions down that path. When we approach life with an attitude of finding the best thoughts we can find, we can find a path through loving kindness, that leads us to solutions that work because they are based on science and self-interest. Do we really want to punish the racist for having attitudes that they were taught to have or do we want to end the problem? We cannot do both. For me, I’d like to leave the world better than I found it so the answer is clear. It is not possible to end racism without benefiting the racist since racism harms the racist.

First, stop identifying YOURSELF as a member of any race but the HUMAN race. Then stop doing that with other people. Second, stop identifying yourself or other people as white or black or red or yellow. These terms separate us into groups of “us” and “others” and are at the heart of racism. (I didn’t include brown because nearly all of us are somewhere between pinky-tan and the dozens of shades of brown, and it’s a continuum.) Third, stop seeing skin color as an extreme dichotomy, as with black/white, as this leads to one being seen as good and one as bad. Catalogue people by types that CROSS the old racist definitions, and see everyone who shares your types as related. But don’t include skin color! For example, people who like this band I like, or people who like hats like mine, or people who have tattoos, or don’t, or people who live in my neighborhood or go to my school, or people in my income bracket. Or people who like this food I like. Or people who like this tv show I like. But don’t see those not in the group as the enemy, but merely as members of different groups with different tastes. Ethnic groupings are not the same as races, so it is easier to use them for good in overturning racism. Some ethnic groupings are very small, and some are transnational. Learn to find all these ethnic grouping interesting and non-threatening. Study them, enjoy them, learn from them (such as skills and foods), but don’t feel that you have to be like them. Anthropology is fascinating. For example, there are many different ethnic groups in Mexico, each with their own customs and food. There are also several in Cuba. Many of the ethnic groups in Mexico share many similarities. Also, Mexicans in general differ in some ways from Cubans in general (or other areas). Explore the differences and enjoy them. This is similar to the way “Native Americans” are made up of hundreds of different ethnic groups that have some things in common but also have many differences. Learn to enjoy difference. Distance yourself from people who aim to dichotomize the human race, no matter what their ancestry. Join some groups. Enjoy other groups. Tolerate what you don’t really enjoy.

Yes, but usually it is not easy, and most racists are not motivated to let go of their racism and are also highly resistant to abandoning their racism. First, define what racism means. I am not one of those people who believe that people of a certain [race] cannot be racists. To me, racism is a learned pattern of behavior that can include aggressive actions against people on the basis of their being capped (or crowned, if you will) as members or as not-members of a certain [race]. If we stay away from the shallow end of the bell curve of racism, the typical racist person will have the mistaken idea that [race] is a valid category, that belonging to a certain [race] determines the possession of each individual therein of a certain list of characteristics, that the possession of some subset of those characteristics is bad, that the word “bad” has objective criteria that back it up. If the description of [race] and racism stopped there, it wouldn’t be so difficult to change. When a person is an objective observer and encounters evidence that invalidates some empirical generalization such as, “All apples are red,” then that person will change that belief. The other aspect of racism, and the part that makes it difficult to change, is that it includes strong components of emotion. Moreover, since racism has been around for a while and has met many challenges from rationalists, there is a complex of emotions and defenses that is difficult to penetrate. Racism is based on in inauthenticity of the individual. At the core of the individual is some version of the belief, “I am bad. I am guilty of really bad sins. I am ashamed of myself for being x, y, z, and having many more defects.” And ( as one student once described himself to me) “I am not worth shit.” I think it is pretty obvious that it took his family, his community, and maybe his nation a decade or two to nurture these beliefs in the individual. They will not go away by themselves. While the individual has these self-condemning beliefs and strong feelings agains himself or herself, a way of defending against, and salving these open lesions of the soul or psyche. The way is to find people who are even worse than oneself, and then to redirect the disgust and hatred one feels for the self out against members of the other [race]. Displaced aggression is found in many situations, e.g., when one beats one’s spouse after being excoriated by one’s boss. The use of [race] gives one a socially constructed target with defenses and rationalization already in place, and social confirmation that one’s racist ideas are affirmed by millions of other people. A few billion flies cannot be wrong about the taste of excrement. Racism is basically a socially constructed phobia. Fear is at the core, and anger can be added to that as a defense against the fear. That way, the unfortunate [black] person takes the punishment for the other person’s lack of authenticity rather than the other person healing the inconsistency at his or her core. The unfortunate [oriental] person takes the punishment for the other person’s “disgusting and shameful” sexual urges that cannot really be denied but can be denied in word and at least through some overt actions. The unfortunate [Jew] takes the payback for the inherited guilt feelings for what one’s own family members did, ironically, to the group they called [Jews, homos, and gypsies]. The fundamental problem is that the racist does not see what is really there and adjust his or her feelings toward others accordingly. The way to treat this problem is to get the person to actually see several members of the hated [race]. Phobia treatment works for things like the panic-inducing fear of baby chicks. Probably the patient in that case is already aware of the irrational aspects of fearing baby chicks.
